In this context, several alternatives have already been proposed for this purpose.[1,2] Among these, the electrochemical energy generation involving hydrogen and oxygen reactions, such as the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), offer considerable advantages from an environmental perspective.[3] These technologies have been the focus of intensive research for several years, and still they need to be more efficient in order to be used for pollutant emissions control since tougher regulations are put in place. Therefore, there are recent advances in energy conversion and storage such as fuel cells,[2] water-splitting devices,[4] metal–air batteries,[5] etc., with important industrial impact in the automotive and
electronics industries. Unfortunately, some of these approaches for clean energy face considerable hurdles, mainly related to the poor thermodynamic efficiency of the reduction and evolution reactions at conventional temperatures and conditions. In order to perform these reactions in an efficient manner, it
With the advent of carbon nanotechnology, which initiated significant research efforts more than two decades ago, novel materials for energy harvesting and storage have emerged at an amazing pace. Nevertheless, some fundamental applications are still dominated by traditional materials, and it is especially evident in the case of catalysis, and environmental-related electrochemical reactions, where precious metals such as Pt and Ir are widely used. Several strategies are being explored for achieving competitive and feasible metal-free carbon nanomaterials, among which doping and defect engineering approaches within nanocarbons are recurrent and promising. Here, the most recent efforts regarding the control of doping and defects in carbon nanostructures for catalysis, and in particular for energy-related applications, are addressed. Finally, an overview of alternative proposals that can make a difference when enabling carbon nanomaterials as efficient and emerging catalysts is presented.

is required that catalytic materials are used throughout the different electrochemical process steps.[6,7]
Efficient catalysts have been in use for the last several decades; however, the nature of such catalysts, e.g., platinum (Pt) and iridium (Ir), implies critical difficulties from the perspective of scarcity and cost. In addition, these classical precious metal catalysts suffer from a quick irreversible loss of catalytic activity when exposed to certain compounds such as carbon monoxide, a phenomenon known as poisoning.[8] For these reasons, tremendous efforts carried out by the scientific community are now being tackled due to an increasing energy demand. In this context, and given the exciting development of carbon nanomaterials during the last two decades, metal-free carbon-based catalysts started to be heavily studied. Carbon is one of the most abundant elements on the Earth’s crust and it is crucial for many living organisms, making it ideal to develop sustainable and environmentally friendly technologies, so it would be an ideal candidate for replacing expensive and potentially inefficient catalysts.
Currently, most of the efforts for producing metal-free catalysts using carbon nanomaterials have been directed toward the usage of doped nanocarbons, which can be defined as carbon structures with tailored physicochemical properties appearing after the introduction of noncarbon atoms within the crystalline network.[9] These nanocarbons have been on the spotlight not only for catalysis but for a myriad of applications, given their attractive properties when compared with the undoped counterparts.[10,11] Research efforts on the catalytic activity of doped nanocarbons including carbon nanotubes (CNTs),[12] graphene,[13] quantum dots,[14] nanoribbons,[15] etc., have led to significant insights on the possible mechanisms behind an increased catalytic activity. Moreover, the role of alternative intrinsic defects within the sp2-hybridized lattice is also becoming relevant for an enhanced catalytic activity.
It is important to mention that the efforts devoted to nanocarbons for metal-free catalysis are not restricted to the use of doped/defective nanocarbons, as discussed below. Chemical treatments, known as functionalization, have also been proposed as an alternative for creating catalytic active sites within nanostructures. In addition, traditional routes for producing activated carbons, i.e., pyrolysis and chemical treatments, will also be reviewed in the context of metal-free nanocarbons for catalysis, especially considering the use of proper organic precursors and frameworks. In summary, here, we provide and overview of recent efforts to utilize engineered doped/defective nano carbons and functionalization routes toward metal-free catalysis, and critically reviewing their real advantages and challenges.

Moreover, the possibility of incorporating functional groups, typically involving oxygenated moieties, is an additional attractive possibility in nanostructured carbons for catalysis. These functionalization processes offer a variety of well-established chemical methods, usually resulting in versatile systems with exciting catalytic properties, being graphene oxide (GO) a popular example of such nanocarbons.

sections.heading: 2.1. Doped Nanocarbons: Synthesis and Catalytic Mechanisms
sections.text:
As mentioned above, doping nanocarbons with elements such as N, B, S, etc., have been traditionally used for synthesizing carbon-based catalysts. The concept of heterodoping has already been in the carbon community for more than two decades,[21,22] with some well-known phenomena occurring at the doping sites, especially in N-doped systems, which have been intensively studied in recent years. In general terms, it is accepted that even though the introduction of noncarbon atoms within the sp2-hybridized carbon network alters the delocalized π electronic structure, the appearance of localized states in the electronic band structure creates reactive sites into the inert graphitic network. These reactive sites thus enable stronger interactions with external molecules, by increasing detection limits when used as sensors,[23–25] or improving nanomaterial dispersibility,[26–28] and even enhancing the vibrational response that give rise to graphene-enhanced Raman scattering applications.[10] In addition, reports about a significant improvement of biocompatibility of N-doped nanocarbons appear in the literature, and these studies also discuss a better dispersibility and surface charges with reduced toxicity.[29–31] In any
case, the actual mechanisms driving the enhancements in biocompatibility could be interrelated with the mechanisms behind other phenomena such as catalysis and/or the inhibition of the formation of reactive oxygen species. Significant efforts toward their utilization in catalysis include dispersions of N-doped CNT on gas diffusion electrodes,[32] yarns made of N-doped CNTs,[33] reduction of GO in the presence of B precursors,[13] exfoliation and simultaneous N-doping of graphene in liquid solvents,[34] or S-doped graphene as efficient catalyst or even as a support for metallic nanoparticles growth,[35] just to mention a few relevant examples.
Figure 2 shows characteristic examples of typical doping configurations for N- and S-codoping, which, among other atomic species, are abundantly reported in the literature and theoretically analyzed. Diverse results on carbon-based catalysis show a relative consensus about an improved catalytic activity of the doping sites within graphitic carbon networks, even though the precise nature of the mechanisms still needs to be elucidated. It is known that each type of heteroatomic doping produces localized electronic charges, which could be centered at the doping site or its surroundings,[10,36] as shown by the electronic charge density isosurfaces depicted in the molecular models of Figure 2 (see details of calculation in ref. [37], using the DFTB+ code).[38–40] By observing the different spatial distribution of charge densities as a function of the doping type, it is clear that the potential catalytic sites could be distant to the actual doping site, as it occurs in for pyrrolic and codoping models, whereas for the other cases, the charge is concentrated in close proxi mity to the doping sites. One recent article by Wang et al.[41] demonstrates experimentally and theoretically that the ORR catalytic activity (in H2SO4 electrolyte) occurs at carbon atoms around N-doping sites in pyridinic configurations. Deeper theoretical attempts to explain the underlying
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (4 of 16)
mechanisms of different dopant heteroatoms within carbon nanostructures are numerous, as well as the results (often contradictory), illustrating the difficulties of explaining the specific processes involved in doped nanocarbons catalysis.
It is important to point out that not only the nature of the heterodoping species influences the overall catalytic activity, but equally important are the nature of the bonding environment of such doping sites, and the concentration of doping. Specifically, the N-contents were found to be in the range between 11.0 and 1.5 at% (which actually could be considered an alloy if N-content were higher than 3.0 at%), depending on the synthesis process, and high ORR activity was found to be preferentially related to the presence of pyridinic N-doping sites according with these reports.[42–44] One particular report by Guo et al.[44] was in fact focused on determining the optimal doping concentration for ORR based on controlled N-doping on highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG), resulting in a linear relationship between ORR activity (under H2SO4 solution as acidic electrolyte) and the amount of pyridinic N-doping sites. One conclusion drawn from this is that an excess of N content would be affecting negatively the catalytic activity, given that not all the N introduced in the sp2-hybridized graphitic networks could be accommodated in pyridinic configuration, decreasing the favorable catalytic activity of the carbon sites around pyridinic N. Furthermore, Figure 3a–d depicts a theoretical study performed by Lee et al. in which a C3N4 system was doped with P and S either replacing C or N atoms, and compared their adsorption energies for OER and ORR intermediates (only OER results are shown in the figure).[45] The authors argued that not only the variation of the (co)doping species, but also their position with respect to the original host system are crucial for an efficient catalytic activity. Likewise, variations in bonding can give rise to defects that promote important modifications on the electronic structure of the graphitic materials, and consequently, their interactions with external species that could lead to improved catalytic properties (see Figure 3e–i). Here, N-doping was analyzed using different pyridinic configurations involving vacancies and geometrical reorganizations within the graphitic structure. The results shown by Wang et al.[42] suggest that the combination of four pyridinic-like N sites and a vacancy (see Figure 3e) exhibits the best ORR/OER performance among all the other configurations, tested under H2SO4 and KOH solutions as electrolytes, respectively. For example, graphene 3D foams with high surface area exhibit remarkable catalytic activity upon nitrogen doping (see Figure 4a,b). For CO2 reduction, these N-doped graphene foams have similar overpotential values as some metals due to the presence of pyridinic N-doping sites within the lattice, with a Faradaic efficiency for CO production of 80% at −0.47 V and better stability than metals.[46] Codoped graphene has also revealed surprising catalytic performance. For instance, nitrogen–phosphorus (N–P)

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (5 of 16)
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (6 of 16)
codoping has been able to render a graphene foam to act as a bifunctional catalyst for ORR and HER using typical KOH and H2SO4 electrolyte solutions (see Figure 4c–e).[47] This material could exhibit an overpotential of 0.06 V for HER and similar stability as Pt/C, and the HER catalysis was remarkably better than many metals and nonmetal catalysts. Regarding ORR, N–P codoping could give similar ORR catalytic activity as Pt/C, with a better stability than Pt/C for 90 h. It is clear that the N–P codoping in graphene could be further optimized for enhanced electrocatalysis, in which the spatial dopant distribution is critical, and where a minimum distance between N and P of 4 Å is desired in order to avoid clustering of the dopants responsible of hindering the electrocatalytic properties.[48] N- and S-codoped graphene has also shown similar HER activity as MoS2, with an onset potential of 0.13 V, a Tafel slope of 80.5 mV decade−1, and an operating potential of 0.28 V at 10 mA cm−2 (see Figure 5a,b). In addition, it has an excellent stability for up to 7 days.[49] Other codoped species such as Si–N should also be tested as they might as well show enhanced catalytic performance.
GO is an interesting nanocarbon by itself, and it is currently the focus of various research efforts. In this regard, GO has been explored as a precursor to synthesize doped nanocarbons. For example, activated reduced GO (rGO) has been studied by Peng et al.,[50] for the oxidation of methylene blue, via peroxymonosulfate. Here, the activated rGO demonstrated a higher oxidation rate than pure peroxymonosulfate. Furthermore, the work by Lin et al.[51] also demonstrated how GO can be doped with N after pyrolysis of mixtures with polymers such as polypyrrole. The resulting material consists of a porous 3D structure with an enhanced catalytic activity and resistance to methanol oxidation, which is a current drawback of commercial Pt/C electrodes. GO has also been doped with nitrogen when flowing NH3 gas at 500 °C and then subjected to a further oxidation using the Hummers’ method,[52] to synthesize N-doped GO quantum dots, as reported by Yeh et al.[14] This material
exhibits p- and n-type semiconductivities according to the Mott−Schottky analysis, and it is capable of absorbing visible light to generate excitons. Interestingly, N-doped GO quantum dots were able to split water in the presence of visible light due to their band gap of 2.2 eV. Their water-splitting activity is half of the metal-based catalysts. In this context, other codopants need to be pursued in order to introduce p- and n-type conductivities, such as B–N, Si–N, P–O, P–S, etc., and to be evaluated for water splitting.
Examples of codoping can also be found in materials derived from adequate precursors, without the use of graphene or GO as intermediate. For example, Figure 5c–f shows a N–P codoped porous carbon resulting from the pyrolysis of aniline in the presence of phytic acid; the material can exhibit ORR and OER activity (in O2-saturated KOH solution as electrolyte). These materials possess large surface areas in the range of 1660 m2 g−1 that make them comparable with other porous carbon materials.[53] The minimum overpotential for ORR and OER is 0.44 and 0.39 V, respectively. It is remarkable that these values are even lower than the best metal catalysts ≈0.45 V for ORR on Pt[54] and ≈0.42 V for OER on RuO2.[55] This catalyst was also proposed to create a rechargeable Zn–air battery.
At this point, the critical parameter that needs to be considered for efficient catalytic performance is to find the “just right” affinity toward the adsorbed reactants to be catalyzed, according to the Sabatier principle.[56] In this regard, the control of the doping configurations and concentrations within doped materials has been pursued intensively.[10,25,41,57] In general, there is an agreement that the precursors used during carbon nanomaterials synthesis have a direct influence on the type and concentration of the doping sites,[12,58] but at least one group argues that the precursors actually have little influence when compared with their N/C ratio.[59] However, the precise control of doping configurations and concentrations would depend on additional factors, such as the synthesis method, type of catalyst used for nanomaterial growth, temperature, and
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (7 of 16)
postprocessing treatments. An illustrative recent example by Li et al.[60] toward the control of doping configurations demonstrate that a combination of precursors with a specific dopant arrangement, such as urea and a polysaccharide (carrageenan), plus carbonization under Ar atmosphere at temperatures ranging from 700 to 1100 °C as postprocessing step, can lead to preferential doping types and location within the nanocarbon structure. Interestingly, the authors argue that by their developed method, the material show preferential formation of S–C in thiophene-fashioned rings at the edges, graphitic N-sites, and pentagon defects, which perform ORR electrocatalysis under acidic (H2SO4 and HClO4 solutions) and alkaline (KOH electrolyte) conditions.

sections.heading: 2.2. Catalytic Properties of Defective Nanocarbons
sections.text:
Since the pioneering research on N-doped carbon nanotube arrays for improved ORR by Gong et al.,[61] extensive efforts have been made to employ various doping species to change the electronic properties and physical characteristics of carbon hosts to achieve attractive ORR performances, potentially competitive with commercial Pt/C. However, contrasting conclusions occur in the heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts for ORR applications. As mentioned above, the site and type of heteroatom doping are crucial in the performance enhancement for metal-free carbon catalysts. For example, nitrogen dopants have four main bonding types including pyridinic, pyrrolic, graphitic, and oxidized nitrogen,[43,51] and their catalytic mechanism has produced controversial debates on the nitrogen active sites, especially about which one among pyridinic-N and graphitic-N plays a dominant role in ORR. Although Nakamura and co-workers utilized HOPG model catalysts to identify the pyridinic-N active sites with high electrocatalytic activity for the ORR under acidic conditions (H2SO4 solution),[44] subsequent research as the one performed by Jiang et al. attributed the discrepancy in catalytic efficiency between pyridinic-N and graphitic-N to a neglection of the vital contribution of intrinsic carbon defects.[62] Usually, defects in carbon nanostructures are classified separately from heteroatom doping, by the fact that defects are generally regarded as topological deviations of the pristine sp2-hybridized carbon network, including vacancies, pentagons and/or heptagons formations, Thrower–Stone– Wales (TSW) defects, etc. Conceptually, these structural defects preserve the carbon-based graphitic lattice without the inclusion of heteroatoms that alter the electronic balance. However, these structural changes modify the atomic orbitals and can result in the creation of localized electronic states that enhance the chemical activity. Many publications have emphasized the importance of defects for many applications,[11] but for catalysis in particular, it has been suggested that high curvature regions (highly strained regions), pentagon defects, vacancies, and edges are comparable in the catalytic performance to heterodoping of nanocarbons.[62] Figure 6 summarizes some of the reported works in this regard, and depicts a general defect classification of carbonaceous materials (Figure 6a–e), in which heteroatomic doping is one of the possibilities. Figure 6f–i summarizes the study performed by Jiang et al.,[62] assessing the catalytic activity of intrinsic carbon defects for oxygen reduction activity in alkaline media (O2-saturated KOH electrolyte). This work is interesting because it involves carbon nanocages that were suitable nanostructures to test edge activity,
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (8 of 16)
high-curvature regions, and related defects. The study was complemented by theoretical calculations on the ORR performance for specific defects, such as pentagons, zigzag and armchair edges, and point vacancies. Remarkably, the authors argued that pentagon defects and zigzag edges exhibit a reduced onset energy, and concluded that some of the apparent confusion, and even conflicting viewpoints in works related to metal-free doped nanocarbons for catalysis, could be understood by considering the role of intrinsic carbon defects. Regarding high strain regions in sp2-hybridized networks, a theoretical report by Chen et al.[63] described a curvature dependence on single-walled CNTs, related to SO adsorption and oxidation reactions, arguing that functional oxygenated groups attached to CNT walls with high curvature (and thus high strain) dramatically promotes the oxidation of SO2 molecules. Additional theoretical works by Chai et al.[64,65] established that TSW defects with specific N-doping configurations facilitate the 4e− reaction pathway for ORR, synergistically operating with high-curvature regions in sp2-hybridized carbon as it occurs in CNTs, for instance. Rybarczyk et al.[66] demonstrated experimentally that doped nanocarbons synthesized in the presence of ZnCl2 and LiCl salts exhibited high curvature regions, which were associated with improved catalytic properties toward ORR in the KOH electrolyte. Previous results have
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (9 of 16)
also indicated much higher ORR activity at the edges of graphite when compared to the basal plane, which was confirmed by DFT calculations revealing a delocalized charge distribution near the graphene edge in HOPG.[67] Recently, Tang et al.[68] also synthesized nanocarbons by direct carbonization of natural gelatinized sticky rice and melamine mixtures, in order to test the performance for ORR and OER for metal-free carbon-based catalysis in HClO4 and KOH solutions as electrolytes. This experimental and theoretical work was focused in identifying the precise roles of topological defects at graphitic edges. The results demonstrated that a nitrogen-free configuration with adjacent pentagons and heptagons had the lowest overpotential for both ORR and OER at the peak position in the volcano plots.[68] Additional works have also addressed the role that defects would play when improving the catalytic performance of electrochemical reactions. Some recent review articles[69–71] discuss the role of defects within nanocarbons for electrocatalysis in more detail. In early 2015, Zhao et al.[72] experimentally explored the relationship between ORR activity (in O2-saturated KOH) and the N-content in PAF-40 derived nanocarbon. A negative relationship was obtained, e.g., the higher the N-content, the lower the ORR activity, which is an unexpected result according to the N-doping mechanism. Accordingly, a new concept of defect mechanism in ORR is presented, in which the topological defects of G585 (containing two pentagons and one octagonal) act as the active sites. Meanwhile, a facile methodology, i.e., the removal of N from the carbon matrix, was proposed to produce such type of defects for ORR. Independently, Xia and co-workers[73] performed theoretical studies using DFT calculations and investigated the different types of defects for ORR. An experiment to carbonize a Zn-based metal organic framework was performed to eliminate the effect of any metallic dopants in ORR.[74] When heated, Zn in the framework would be released by evaporation (a process similar to the N release aforementioned), which would create the unique defective carbon structure. The results indicated the resulting “pure” carbon structure (containing only C and O) exhibited excellent ORR activity in alkaline KOH electrolyte: same onset potential as Pt/C with 4e− pathway, which confirmed the role of defects within nanocarbons for ORR. This is the first example to display a carbon structure without the socalled heteroatom doping highly active for ORR. Incidentally, the Zn evaporation is now becoming a popular method to produce defective carbons, especially for trapping atomic metal species.[75,76] This new defect mechanism was subsequently applied to other structures such as activated carbons derived from coal[77] and biomass.[78] Furthermore, defective graphene materials were synthesized from N-containing precursors, using a simple nitrogen removal procedure, which creates various types of defects for multifunctional catalysis; not only ORR, but also for HER and OER.[79] In this report, the authors investigated the ORR activity (carried out in O2-saturated KOH) of defective nanocarbons by direct observations of various types of defects using aberration-corrected high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, and further confirmed that specific topological defects, such as pentagons, G585, and 7557 (containing carbon rings with heptagon-pentagon-pentagon-heptagon), located at the edges could significantly enhance the catalytic activities, by theoretical calculations and experimental characterization. This research demonstrated feasible mechanism routes for electrocatalysis by incorporating structural defects within nanocarbons. Switching now the focus toward proposed routes for experimentally produced nanocarbons with controlled defect structure, several methods have been explored and reported, such as a plasma technique that has been recently employed to treat the carbon materials for creating a large number of defects on their surfaces in metal-free carbon-based catalysis. Here, Tao et al.[80] utilized Ar plasma to etch the surfaces of graphene and CNTs, in order to produce defective nanocarbons, which exhibited enhanced ORR performances when compared to the pristine counterparts. The results were ascribed to the presence of exposed defects acting as the active sites for ORR electrolysis. In a similar process, Liu et al.[81] also used Ar plasma to irradiate carbon fibers to achieve edge-rich, oxygen functionalized graphene on their surfaces with high specific surface area, good intrinsic electron conductivity, excellent mass transport, and an increased number of active sites for the enhanced ORR/OER activities (measured in KOH solutions), which was predicated by DFT calculations. Besides oxygen electrocatalysis, HER electrocatalytic performances were improved when 3D porous graphene, a high content N-doping and rich structural defective nanocarbon, was used as a catalyst.[82] In this study, the plasmainduced defective samples could significantly improve the HER activity with a low overpotential of 128 mV at 10 mA cm−2, as compared to the sole N-doped counterpart, thus indicating that defects in carbon lattices play a key role in electrocatalytic activity. Defective carbons with high ratio of edges could be obtained not only by introducing the defects into carbon lattices through plasma or other aggressive post-treatment processes, but also from adequate precursors and methods, e.g., carbonaceous gas or biomass, by plasma-assisted synthesis process. We utilized the microwave plasma irradiation technique to bombard biomass (rice husk and residual coffee grounds) in order to successfully fabricate different graphene-based carbon materials including vertical graphene, graphenated CNTs, which are graphene sheets grown on the walls of CNTs, and graphene-sheet fibers, which possess a large amount of defects and open edges (high ID/IG ratio).[83,84] Current experiments have confirmed that plasma-synthesized vertical graphene displays higher ORR performances than some N-doped CNTs, thus clearly confirming the significant contribution of carbon defects in electrocatalysis. It is clear that a considerable fraction of the research on metal-free carbon-based catalysis has been focused on the role of doping, with some variations in terms of heterodoping species (codoping) and the nature of doping sites within the host carbon network. Moreover, contributions to the field related to intrinsic structural and topological defects, like those addressed above, are helping us to develop a more complete picture of the mechanisms responsible for an enhanced catalytic activity. However, there is a debate on the possible underlying causes for the catalytic activity of these nanocarbons. While theoretical calculations have shown that many of the catalytic reactions are possible by defect engineering, recently it has been pointed out that, at least in GO derived nanocarbons, the catalytic activity can be in part due to traces of metallic/oxide residues, such as
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (10 of 16)
MnO traces resulting from the KMnO4, or metallic traces in mineral graphite used during the GO preparation.[85–87] The effect of metallic traces has also been found in the preparation of other nanocarbons for the ORR reaction using polymeric precursors with metal contamination,[88] and it has been shown that the catalytic activity of CNTs was also linked to metallic residues.[89,90] However, theoretical and experimental studies have demonstrated that the effects of doping, in combination with intrinsic topological defects, are undoubtedly exerting positive effects on the catalytic properties of nanocarbons, thus making the term metal-free carbon-based catalysis a worth term for further research and development.

sections.heading: 3. Surface Chemical Functionalized Carbons for Metal-Free Catalysis
sections.text:
Once we consider all the efforts aiming at developing metalfree carbon-based catalysts, and after observing that a considerable amount of research has been devoted to doping of carbon nanostructures, it is worth to explore further and simpler complementary methods for generating alternatives toward cheap and relatively efficient catalytic nanocarbons. In this regard, we emphasize functionalization, which implies the chemical modification of the surface of nanostructured carbon materials by grafting specific molecules or group of molecules onto the graphitic sp2-hybridized surfaces. Functionalization is a postprocessing method with a wide range of uses: from simple oxidative chemical or physical treatments for covalently attaching oxygenated groups, such as epoxy, carboxylic acids, and hydroxyls, to complex functionalization methods also able to produce specific molecular arrangements, such as the azomethine ylides reacting in double bonds in graphitic networks to produce pyrrolic derivatives.[91] The methods for functionalization can be as diverse as the possible combinations of moieties that can be attached to graphitic structures. For example, the oxidative chemical methods usually imply the use of mixtures of strong acids, such as H2SO4, HNO3, etc., for disrupting the sp2-hybridized carbon network (see Figure 7a). The process results in different proportions of oxygenated groups formed at the edges, ends and defect points of the carbon nanostructures. Noncovalent functionalization is possible also by means of π–π interactions with aromatic molecules such as pyrene, and their corresponding derivatives (see Figure 7b).[92] This route has the advantage of preserving the structural integrity of the carbon sp2 network, and hence could maintain the high electrical conductivity of CNTs or graphene noncovalently functionalized, which is a desirable characteristic for electrocatalytic materials. Figure 7c represents the variety of equivalent functionalization for graphene, which has been demonstrated to have a utility for catalytic applications, as it has been comprehensively addressed by Dai.[93] Moreover, GO, which was discussed in previous sections as a base material for producing doped nanocarbons with catalytic properties, represents by itself a model of pure functionalized nanocarbons for metal-free catalysis. Figure 7d depicts a typical figure for GO with a variety of oxygen functional groups covalently attached to the carbon network. These functional groups have been studied in some extent, somewhat related to the characterization of active catalytic sites for
activated porous carbons.[94] For instance, research groups coordinated by Su and co-workers have demonstrated that CNTs functionalized with less negative oxygen groups can be effective in the reduction of nitrogen-based organic compounds.[95] Furthermore, studies on the synergistic effect of oxygen functional groups and N-doping sites in doped GO improve its catalytic performance for ORR (see Figure 7e).[96] These reports demonstrate that functionalization, which in some extent is a simple way to process carbon nanomaterials, could be a feasible route for tailoring their catalytic properties.
Further reports on the specific activities of common functional groups in carbon nanostructures, such as oxygenated moieties, point to an active role in catalytic processes. For example, oxygen groups are of utmost relevance for carbon nanomaterials given that they are part of common chemical routes for other functionalization paths, or even natural to materials such as GO, as discussed above. Figure 8 depicts a couple of examples reported in this topic: Zhang et al.[97] described an experimental/theoretical study on the catalytic activity of modified CNTs for oxidative dehydrogenation of organic compounds, which involves the cleavage of specific bonds driven by charge transfers at active oxygenated functional groups attached to CNTs (see Figure 8a,b). The method for modifying the surface of CNTs involved their chemical oxidation by refluxing them in strong acids (HNO3 in this case), thus producing a wide variety of functional groups. However, the authors identified the key activity role of ketonic CO groups for attacking electron-lacking saturated bonds due to their nucleophilic nature with high electron density. Further treatments of the oxidized CNTs using phosphate species resulted in a decrease of the catalytic activity, but an increased selectivity toward the formation of alkenes by oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes. In the same matter, Figure 8c–e depicts molecular models of graphene clusters with oxygen functional groups (lactone and ketone), analyzed theoretically (based on experimental results) in a report by Lu et al.,[98] describing the energy profiles for water oxidation reactions in three different configurations of functional groups on the graphene surface. Interestingly, the three screened molecular models shown feasible reaction routes for water oxidation, going from H2O to O2 by OH, O, and OOH intermediates, with two models involving ketone functional groups. Moreover, the authors described a phenomenon observed in theoretical analyses on doped nanocarbons, which is the adsorption/catalysis toward the intermediates atop carbons in the proximity of the functionalized sites. Thus, it can be concluded that specific functional groups attached to the sp2-hybridized network in nanocarbons would have important roles in catalytic processes.
Figure 9 shows further examples of recent efforts toward the synthesis of metal-free carbon-based catalysts, by the combination of some of the common nanocarbons together with chemical processing methods. In this context, Zhang et al.[99] propose a simple and feasible method for imparting catalytic properties to conventional multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), by wrapping them with polymers such as poly(ethylene-alt-maleic acid), poly(vinyl alcohol), poly(vinyl acetate), poly(ethylene glycol), etc., all of them containing polar oxygen groups (see Figure 9a–f). The resulting material was easily casted for the fabrication of a membrane, which was thereafter tested successfully
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (11 of 16)
for electrocatalytic OER properties. This method poses several key advantages: first, it makes use of pure MWCNTs, which are among the most popular nanocarbons, with current industrial yields in the range of thousands of tons per year globally. Second, the postprocessing for polymer wrapping is carried out without covalent bonding, thus facilitating the overall fabrication of composite membranes for catalytic applications.
The functionalization of carbon nanostructures has been successfully proposed as an alternative route for imparting them with catalytic properties, which could be complementary to, or even substitute the heteroatomic doping in nanocarbons. Functionalization, as it involves chemical processes, poses several advantages in terms of the wide variety of molecules that can be attached to the carbonaceous walls, with a consequential wide variety of catalytic activities driven by specific functional groups. However, functionalization is generally a postprocessing phase, usually involving time-consuming steps and many (frequently dangerous) reactants. This contrasts with the convenience of engineered doping or defects structuring within nanocarbons synthesis phase. However, in the light of the recent results, functionalization should be further explored for developing feasible metal-free catalytic carbon nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 4. Catalytic Nanocarbons from Annealing/Pyrolysis of Ordered Organic Structures
sections.text:
The annealing as postprocessing, or the direct pyrolysis of controlled organic structures aimed at producing nanocarbonbased materials with high catalytic activity, constitute additional routes that are worth to be explored for the addition of functional groups, defects or doping sites with attractive catalytic activity. An interesting example, which takes advantage of the fabrication of 3D graphene networks grown on templates of Ni foams (see Figure 9g–m) was proposed by Zhou, Chen, et al.[100] These 3D networks exhibited remarkable features inherent to their high surface area, which increases upon Ar plasma treatments and the subsequent doping via thermal annealing in phenothiazine (the N- and S-doping precursor), from ≈3000 to ≈4500 m2 g−1. Actually, the use of ionized precursor gases for doping presynthesized nanostructured materials by plasma or thermal annealing has also gained terrain as postprocessing method for synthesizing carbon-based catalysts. In this context, it is possible to use the synthesis of reduced GO as a direct way to produce graphite-like surfaces on a variety of substrates.[19,57] Figure 9n–p depicts a proposal by Xu et al.[101] for constructing a porous catalytic carbon material with a high degree of microstructure control after pyrolyzing covalent organic frameworks (COFs). It consists of an arrangement of stacked 2D macromolecules from organic building blocks (1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyltrianiline (TATP) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalaldehyde (DHTA)), which after pyrolysis in the presence of phytic acid, results in a nitrogen- and phosphorous-doped porous-carbon semi-ordered structure. The authors state that this pyrolyzed material exhibits a good degree of sp2-hybridized carbon for high electron conductivity as well as high quantities of N- and P-doping sites for efficient metal-free catalysis for ORR under alkaline conditions (O2- or N2-saturated KOH solution). In further work by Qian et al.[102] on the pyrolysis of a zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF), the formation of a web-like interconnected carbon network with efficient oxygen reduction catalysis was described. The pyrolysis of a ZIF and NaCl mixture, above the NaCl melting point (around 800 °C), produces a 3D carbon structure with high content of nitrogen and, according with the authors, a convenient pore size distribution responsible of facilitating the mass transfer and catalytic activity toward ORR (in O2-saturated KOH solution). The effect of molten NaCl as templating for the special structure was well characterized, and proved to be an easy and efficient way to produce interconnected carbons during pyrolysis. Moreover, tests of the web-like structures in a primary Zn–air battery, resulted in an improved durability of the nanocarbon-based catalyst; more than 140 h when compared to 50 h of Pt/C electrodes. These few works demonstrate the feasibility of using annealing and pyrolysis processes for carbonization/restructuring of predefined organic structures. The advantages of these
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (13 of 16)
methods rely on the high degree of control of the doping ratio, pore/defects distribution and the resulting microstructure, which ultimately has direct implications on the performance of metal-free catalysts. As for disadvantages, it could be stated that, as it occurs with the functionalization of nanocarbons, thermal treatments on organic frameworks comprise several steps, which could hinder their scaling up. However, the key factor of being able to precisely tune the doping ratio and, up to some degree, the micro/nanostructuring of the produced materials, should be attractive for further developments of metalfree catalysts that can compete with conventional materials.

sections.heading: 5. Perspectives on Nanocarbons for Metal-Free Catalysis
sections.text:
In the 21st century, energy, natural resources, and environmental sustainability appear as key societal topics, and technological innovations in all these areas are indispensable. In this context, carbon nanomaterials are expected to be essential in these advances. Since the 1970s, carbon science has contributed with technological innovations going from polyacrylonitrile (PAN)-based and mesophase pitch-based carbon fibers, diamond-like carbon, and carbon anodes for lithium ion batteries, to carbon nanotechnology advances, related to fullerenes, CNTs and graphene. Following this trend on carbon science, metal free catalytic nanocarbons constitute an important step toward applied carbon nanotechnology for solving critical societal issues. Here, we summarize some recent efforts aimed to solve urgent needs in metal-free catalysis applications, and could be considered as crossroads of energy and environmental sustainability. The developed science on the underlying mechanisms of doped/defective nanocarbons, as well as the role of such features in their catalytic performances, have fueled a wide variety of research, with copious results. Some degree of consensus on the importance of specific types of doping, e.g., pyridinic-N or graphitic-N, edges, N–S or N–P codoping, etc., has been established. Looking forward, we envisage that
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1805717
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1805717 (14 of 16)
not only the precise control on the doping and defect types, but also, finer engineering on structural formation toward 3D structuring, could lead to efficient carbon nanostructures for metal-free catalysis and other related applications. According to the works summarized here, it could be argued that the most promising routes for controlling doping structure and defect morphology in a precise manner, should involve the bottom-up approach. For instance, the synthesis of organic frameworks from specific building blocks, combined with postprocessing steps including carbonization, chemical treatments, etc., can produce very regular structures with well-defined atomic species ratios and configurations. Moreover, as mentioned in this report, functionalization of carbon structures can in principle lead to very specific types of anchored chemical groups, with relatively easy ways to control their concentration. Furthermore, the use of new and more precise structural characterization techniques (aberration corrected electron microscopy, X-ray absorption and photoelectron spectroscopies, advanced scanning transmission electron microscopy, etc.) which can reveal the detailed bonding environment and charge spatial distribution of doping and defective sites, combined with new computational tools for reaction path simulations, intermediates determination and electron density for different atomic configurations, will continue to expand the fundamental understanding of the precise mechanisms behind the catalytic activity of engineered nanocarbons.
It could be considered now that the discussion about the development of metal-free nanocarbons for catalysis is not only focused on the structuring, doping and overall performance, but lately, addressing feasible synthesis routes, which are environmentally friendly and scalable, are becoming more relevant. Along this direction, we reviewed reports on alternative methods for producing such catalytic nanocarbons. Importantly, the potential of functionalization of CNTs and graphene with appropriate molecules, probably combined with heterodoping, has been relatively unexplored and could represent an alternative for an easy fabrication of metal-free catalytic materials. Moreover, some of the works summarized here address the evaluation of nanocarbons-based catalysis under acidic conditions, which is of critical importance for practical developments such as high-performance fuel cells and related technologies. If further developments keep this perspective of exploring alternative routes for catalytic nanocarbons synthesis, whilst considering practicality toward their usability, we expect major impacts on novel energy technologies, with increasing participation and investment from industrial sectors. From our point of view, the methods summarized herein represent feasible routes for developing clean energy technologies, thus making the fabrication of efficient nanocarbon-based catalytic materials a sustainable and cost-effective process when compared with precious metals.
Another important advantage of using doped nanocarbons for catalytic materials, as mentioned above, is the inherent safety toward living organisms and their environment. Many of the current energy technologies are related to materials that need to be carefully handled after their utility-life period, and discarded in a very controlled way (Ni–Cd batteries, heavy metals compounds). For example, there are reports on increasing quantities of environmental available Pd, Rh, and Pt, which are detectable in living organisms in urban areas. The reports attribute these
increasing catalytic metals accumulation to the extended use of catalytic converters, which produce airborne particulate matter.[103,104] These issues would be attenuated or eliminated by the use of catalysts based on doped carbon nanomaterials, given the extensive studies that support the superior biocompatibility and safety of N-doped carbon nanostructures, tested from unicellular model organisms such as Entamoeba histolytica to complex animals such as mice and humans.[29–31] As mentioned above, the exact nature of the improved biocompatibility of such novel safe nanocarbons is not totally understood up to date, in a similar way as the observed catalytic performance in doped/defective nanocarbons is explained by different mechanisms. This highlights the importance of the current efforts toward unveiling the fundamental phenomena of doping/ defective sites by experimental and theoretical means, for the design of safe nanostructures as catalysts.
In summary, we have addressed the importance of doped/ defective nanocarbons for the development of metal-free catalytic materials. Different methodologies for controlling the dopant concentration, as well as structural configuration within nanostructured carbon hosts, were overviewed and discussed. Alternatives readily available for carbon nanomaterials, such as functionalization, as well as pyrolysis of ordered organic structures, were also analyzed in terms of their contribution toward engineered nanocarbons for metal-free catalysis.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/adma.201805717 In this context, several alternatives have already been proposed for this purpose.[1,2] Among these, the electrochemical energy generation involving hydrogen and oxygen reactions, such as the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), offer considerable advantages from an environmental perspective.[3] These technologies have been the focus of intensive research for several years, and still they need to be more efficient in order to be used for pollutant emissions control since tougher regulations are put in place. Therefore, there are recent advances in energy conversion and storage such as fuel cells,[2] water-splitting devices,[4] metal–air batteries,[5] etc., with important industrial impact in the automotive and electronics industries. Unfortunately, some of these approaches for clean energy face considerable hurdles, mainly related to the poor thermodynamic efficiency of the reduction and evolution reactions at conventional temperatures and conditions. In order to perform these reactions in an efficient manner, it With the advent of carbon nanotechnology, which initiated significant research efforts more than two decades ago, novel materials for energy harvesting and storage have emerged at an amazing pace. Nevertheless, some fundamental applications are still dominated by traditional materials, and it is especially evident in the case of catalysis, and environmental-related electrochemical reactions, where precious metals such as Pt and Ir are widely used. Several strategies are being explored for achieving competitive and feasible metal-free carbon nanomaterials, among which doping and defect engineering approaches within nanocarbons are recurrent and promising. Here, the most recent efforts regarding the control of doping and defects in carbon nanostructures for catalysis, and in particular for energy-related applications, are addressed. Finally, an overview of alternative proposals that can make a difference when enabling carbon nanomaterials as efficient and emerging catalysts is presented. Catalytic Nanocarbons
